title: Tyntesfield Walks

images.title: Duncan Grey / The walled kitchen garden
images.caption: The walled kitchen garden. Lilies in the water reservoir and only half the plot is currently in use, but this could be a capacious vegetable plot.

images.title: Ray Beer / Entrance to the Vegetable Gardens
images.caption: Entrance to the Vegetable Gardens

images.title: The aviary at Tyntesfield, awaiting restoration by Carol Walker, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The aviary at Tyntesfield, awaiting restoration in 2010.

images.title: Adrian and Janet Quantock / Station Lodge
images.caption: Station Lodge. Gate on left of picture is a private entrance into the the estate. Public entrance is via the B3128.

images.title: Martin Bodman / Wraxall: Watercress Farm
images.caption: Wraxall: Watercress Farm. The farm at one time belonged to the Tyntesfield estate, now National Trust. The farmhouse has been rebuilt following a fire in the 1980s. In 2006 work is now in progress to convert outbuildings. Two little water-powered pump houses here provided water for Tyntesfield House. Looking north west

description: This Victorian Gothic Revival house near the Bristol is surrounded by 150 acres (61 ha) of parkland and gardens which are perfect for a peaceful walk. You can explore the woodland, the tree lined drive, the delightful rose garden, the walled kitchen garden, summer houses, and the aviary - all with the rolling Somerset hills as beautiful backdrop. The Home Farm Visitor Centre houses the Cow Barn kitchen, gift shop and garden shop. Tyntesfield is located about 4 miles west of Bristol, near Nailsea and Clevedon .
